page.title: 11THE RAILWAY
page.content: The Railway first came to Didcot in 1844. 90 Full-time staff work at the station itself. It has recently been modernised. The platforms have been raised. A completely new and attractive front and forecourt were completed in 1985. Some drivers have worked at Didcot for 46 years. Mr Alder has worked there for 30 years and he is retiring in 1986. He tells that the sheds were built with scraps from London roundabout 1933. Fewer trains come through Didcot now, although it is a major junction for Westbound trains from Paddington, London and for Northbound trains from the South coast. One of the first engines to come through Didcot was one of Stevenson's. In the 1950's it cost 4s6d to go to London by train from Didcot. In 1985 it costs 6 pounds.
